articles.headline: Retailers Stumble Adjusting to More Selective Shoppers
articles.snippet: In earnings reports this week, companies showed it has been a struggle to adapt to a consumer mind-set that is vastly different from what it was during much of the pandemic.
articles.abstract: In earnings reports this week, companies showed it has been a struggle to adapt to a consumer mind-set that is vastly different from what it was during much of the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: This hasn’t been the year retailers planned for.

articles.headline: ‘I’m Carrying This Baby Just to Bury It’: The Struggle to Decode Abortion Laws
articles.snippet: At a Louisiana hospital, concerns about complying with new abortion bans in post-Roe America left a pregnant woman with a devastating diagnosis, but not an abortion.
articles.abstract: At a Louisiana hospital, concerns about complying with new abortion bans in post-Roe America left a pregnant woman with a devastating diagnosis, but not an abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nancy Davis says that when she learned this month that the fetus she was carrying had a rare and fatal condition, she and her partner were devastated.
articles.byline: By Ava Sasani and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: A Famous Walrus Is Killed, and Norwegians Are Divided
articles.snippet: The killing of Freya has polarized Oslo and threatens to blight the image of a country more commonly associated with diplomatic good deeds than mob-like hits.
articles.abstract: The killing of Freya has polarized Oslo and threatens to blight the image of a country more commonly associated with diplomatic good deeds than mob-like hits.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO — It was another good day for Freya, the 1,300-pound walrus named for the Norse goddess of love, beauty and war, who had become a beloved and feel-good international media sensation, the frolicking mascot of the long Oslo summer.

articles.headline: After Signing Climate Bill, Biden Prepares More Actions to Cut Emissions
articles.snippet: Regulations from the E.P.A. and elsewhere will help the president meet his aggressive climate goals, administration officials say.
articles.abstract: Regulations from the E.P.A. and elsewhere will help the president meet his aggressive climate goals, administration officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh off signing expansive climate legislation, President Biden and his administration are planning a series of executive actions to further reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help keep the planet from warming to dangerous temperatures, senior White House officials said.
articles.byline: By Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Some Colleges Don’t Produce Big Earners. Are They Worth It?
articles.snippet: Many attendees aren’t better off financially than those who have only a high school degree, at least not right away. How should applicants consider these institutions?
articles.abstract: Many attendees aren’t better off financially than those who have only a high school degree, at least not right away. How should applicants consider these institutions?
articles.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s student debtors enter Month 20 of awaiting word on when or if President Biden will keep his promise to cancel some of their debt, many questions hang in the air.

articles.headline: How the Find My App Became an Accidental Friendship Fixture
articles.snippet: Introduced 10 years ago, the app has slowly become a popular way to keep track of friends. But it comes with considerable privacy concerns.
articles.abstract: Introduced 10 years ago, the app has slowly become a popular way to keep track of friends. But it comes with considerable privacy concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July, Shay Pierre opened Apple’s location-sharing app Find My and noticed a friend at an unfamiliar apartment building in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

articles.headline: How Pharmacy Work Stopped Being So Great
articles.snippet: Two years of economic recovery brought strong gains to workers at the top and the bottom, but headwinds for those in between. Consider the pharmacist.
articles.abstract: Two years of economic recovery brought strong gains to workers at the top and the bottom, but headwinds for those in between. Consider the pharmacist.
articles.lead_paragraph: If any group of workers might have expected their pay to rise last year, it would arguably have been pharmacists. With many drugstores dispensing coronavirus tests and vaccines while filling hundreds of prescriptions each day, working as a pharmacist became a sleep-deprived, lunch-skipping frenzy — one in which ornery customers did not hesitate to vent their frustrations over the inevitable backups and bottlenecks.

articles.headline: The Final Days of the Trump White House: Chaos and Scattered Papers
articles.snippet: Government documents that President Donald J. Trump had accumulated were with him in roughly two dozen boxes in the White House residence. They were to go to the National Archives, but at least some ended up in Florida.
articles.abstract: Government documents that President Donald J. Trump had accumulated were with him in roughly two dozen boxes in the White House residence. They were to go to the National Archives, but at least some ended up in Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four days before the end of the Trump presidency, a White House aide peered into the Oval Office and was startled, if not exactly surprised, to see all of the president’s personal photos still arrayed behind the Resolute Desk as if nothing had changed — guaranteeing the final hours would be a frantic dash mirroring the prior four years.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Katie Benner and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: How a Storied Phrase Became a Partisan Battleground
articles.snippet: A touchstone of political and social discourse, the nearly 100-year-old phrase “the American dream,” is being repurposed — critics say distorted — particularly by Republicans of color.
articles.abstract: A touchstone of political and social discourse, the nearly 100-year-old phrase “the American dream,” is being repurposed — critics say distorted — particularly by Republicans of color.
articles.lead_paragraph: Juan Ciscomani, a Republican who washed cars to help his Mexican immigrant father pay the bills and is now running for Congress in Arizona, has been leaning on a simple three-word phrase throughout his campaign — “the American dream.”

articles.headline: ‘Cable Cowboy’ John Malone Sees More Streaming Bundles Ahead
articles.snippet: The media mogul also said news channels should do a better job of distinguishing between news and opinion.
articles.abstract: The media mogul also said news channels should do a better job of distinguishing between news and opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last year, the longtime media heavyweight John Malone made a prediction about a big change coming in the film and TV industry.

articles.headline: A Dad Took Photos of His Naked Toddler for the Doctor. Google Flagged Him as a Criminal.
articles.snippet: Google has an automated tool to detect abusive images of children. But the system can get it wrong, and the consequences are serious.
articles.abstract: Google has an automated tool to detect abusive images of children. But the system can get it wrong, and the consequences are serious.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: What Russians See in the News: A War Over Western Plans to Subjugate Them
articles.snippet: In the Kremlin-controlled news media, the war is not about Ukraine, but about a long history of enemies trying to keep Russia down.
articles.abstract: In the Kremlin-controlled news media, the war is not about Ukraine, but about a long history of enemies trying to keep Russia down.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Vesti Nedeli,” the flagship weekly roundup of Kremlin-controlled television news, recently portrayed a long history of predatory Western powers coming to grief when they invaded Russia: Sweden in the 18th century, France in the 19th, Germany in the 20th.

articles.headline: Is a Fetus a Person? An Anti-Abortion Strategy Says Yes.
articles.snippet: Fetal personhood, which confers legal rights from conception, is an effort to push beyond abortion bans and classify the procedure as murder. In Georgia, it also means a $3,000 tax credit.
articles.abstract: Fetal personhood, which confers legal rights from conception, is an effort to push beyond abortion bans and classify the procedure as murder. In Georgia, it also means a $3,000 tax credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Brazen Attack Near Moscow Rattles Russians
articles.snippet: The daughter of a prominent ultranationalist, herself a hawkish commentator, was killed by a car bomb deep in Russian territory.
articles.abstract: The daughter of a prominent ultranationalist, herself a hawkish commentator, was killed by a car bomb deep in Russian territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: A brazen car bombing in a Moscow suburb that killed the daughter of a prominent backer of President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has injected new uncertainty into the six-month war and rattled Russia’s elite.

articles.headline: More Than ‘Weird’: Roku Embraces Original Programming
articles.snippet: The streaming media device company wants to attract more viewers and advertisers to its channel. A coming biopic of “Weird Al” Yankovic is its most ambitious project to date.
articles.abstract: The streaming media device company wants to attract more viewers and advertisers to its channel. A coming biopic of “Weird Al” Yankovic is its most ambitious project to date.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gray, rainy weather of an early March day was no match for the joy emanating from a rented bungalow on the campus of the California State Polytechnic University in Pomona.

articles.headline: Expansion of Clean Energy Loans Is ‘Sleeping Giant’ of Climate Bill
articles.snippet: The bill President Biden signed into law recently will greatly expand government loans and loan guarantees for clean energy and automotive projects and businesses.
articles.abstract: The bill President Biden signed into law recently will greatly expand government loans and loan guarantees for clean energy and automotive projects and businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tucked into the Inflation Reduction Act that President Biden signed last week is a major expansion of federal loan programs that could help the fight against climate change by channeling more money to clean energy and converting plants that run on fossil fuels to nuclear or renewable energy.

articles.headline: An Unusual $1.6 Billion Donation Bolsters Conservatives
articles.snippet: A low-profile Republican financier donated his company to a new group run by the influential operative Leonard A. Leo.
articles.abstract: A low-profile Republican financier donated his company to a new group run by the influential operative Leonard A. Leo.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new conservative nonprofit group scored a $1.6 billion windfall last year via a little-known donor — an extraordinary sum that could give Republicans and their causes a huge financial boost ahead of the midterms, and for years to come.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: A Supplier of Rare Earth Metals Turns to Greenland in a Bid to Cut Reliance on Russia
articles.snippet: Neo Performance Materials of Canada announced a deal to begin mining in Greenland for the metals, which are a key component for electric cars.
articles.abstract: Neo Performance Materials of Canada announced a deal to begin mining in Greenland for the metals, which are a key component for electric cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One of the world’s last processors of rare earth metals outside China is buying mining rights in Greenland to reduce dependence on Russian ore and stabilize prices, in the latest move by Western companies to diversify supply chains following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: What Are the Real Warning Signs of a Mass Shooting?
articles.snippet: While some mass shootings are committed by people with diagnosed mental illnesses, a life crisis is a better predictor of violence, researchers say.
articles.abstract: While some mass shootings are committed by people with diagnosed mental illnesses, a life crisis is a better predictor of violence, researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
